Constuction of R and basic topology
Review of algebraic and order properties of R, ϵ-neighborhood of a point in R. Idea of count-
able sets, uncountable sets and uncountability of R. Bounded above sets, bounded below sets,
bounded sets, unbounded sets. Suprema and inﬁma. Construction of Reals from Rationals, Can-
tor’s nested interval Theorem, Completeness property of R and its equivalent properties. The
Archimedean property, density of rational (and irrational) numbers in R, intervals. Limit points
of a set, isolated points, open set, closed set, derived set, Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem for sets,
compact sets in R, Heine-Borel Theorem.
Sequences
Sequences, bounded sequence, convergent sequence, limit of a sequence, lim inf, lim sup. Limit
theorems. Monotone sequences, monotone convergence theorem. Subsequences, divergence cri-
teria. Monotone subsequence theorem, Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem for sequences. Cauchy
sequence, Cauchy’s convergence criterion.
Series
Inﬁnite series, convergence and divergence of inﬁnite series, Cauchy criterion, tests for conver-
gence: comparison test, limit comparison test, D’Alembert’s test, Raabe’s test, Cauchy’s nth
root test, Gauss test, Logarithmic test, Integral test. Alternating series, Leibniz test. Abso-
lute and conditional convergence, Rearrangement of series, Riemann’s theorem on conditionally
convergent series. [50]

Deﬁnition 1.2 (Functions)
A function, map or mapping f : A → B is an association of every element a ∈ A
with some f(a) ∈ B. Moreover f is:
1. an injection or one-to-one function iﬀ (∀x, y ∈ A) f(x) = f(y) =⇒ x = y;
2. a surjection or onto function iﬀ (∀b ∈ B) ∃a ∈ A : b = f(a);
3. a bijection or one-to-one correspondence iﬀ it is both of the above.
We denote the domain of f , A, by D
f
= A. We deﬁne the range of f as R
f
=
f(A) = {f(a) : a ∈ A}. So f is surjective iﬀ f(A) = B.

An isomorphism between two algebraic structures (G, ◦) and (H, ⋆) is a homo-

An isomorphism from a group onto itself is an automorphism.

Deﬁnition 1.6 (Equivalence Relations and Classes)
A relation ∼ on a set X is an equivalence relation iﬀ:
1. x ∈ X =⇒ x ∼ x (reﬂexive)
2. x, y ∈ X : x ∼ y =⇒ y ∼ x (symmetric)
3. x, y, z ∈ X : x ∼ y , y ∼ z =⇒ x ∼ z (transitive)
The equivalence class of an element a ∈ X is deﬁned as:
[a] = {x ∈ X : a ∼ x}.
Example 1.7
A collection of mathematical objects isomorphic to each other forms an equivalence
class, which we call the isomorphism class of those objects.
Example 1.8 (Natural numbers)
The set N ∪ {0} = {0, 1, 2, 3, . . . } can be deﬁned in several ways:
1. As ﬁnite ordinals: 0 = {} = ∅, succesor s(n) = n ∪ {n} with s(0) := 1.
2. As ﬁnite cardinals: isomorphism classes of ﬁnite sets.
3. As strings over a unary alphabet: “”, “a”, “aa”, “aaa”, . . . .
Here we consider the natural numbers to be the set N, excluding 0.

Deﬁnition 1.12 (Types of Properties of Binary Operations)
Let G = ∅ be a set and ◦ be a binary operation deﬁned on G. Then:
1. Closure property: G is closed w.r.t. ◦ iﬀ a, b ∈ G =⇒ a ◦ b ∈ G.
2. Associativity: a, b, c ∈ G =⇒ a ◦ (b ◦ c) = (a ◦ b) ◦ c.
3. Commutativity: a, b ∈ G =⇒ a ◦ b = b ◦ a.
4. Existence of identity element: ∃e ∈ G : a = a ◦ e = e ◦ a ∀a ∈ G.
5. Existence of inverses: ∀a ∈ G ∃ a
−1
∈ G : a ◦ a
−1
= a
−1
◦ a = e.
Deﬁnition 1.13 (Groupoid, Semigroup, Monoid)
Let G = ∅ be a set and ◦ be a binary operation deﬁned on G. Then:
1. The pair (G, ◦) is a groupoid iﬀ ◦ is closed w.r.t. G.
2. The groupoid (G, ◦) is a semigroup iﬀ ◦ is associative.
3. The semigroup (G, ◦) is a monoid iﬀ ◦ has existence of identity element.
Deﬁnition 1.14 (Group Axioms)
Let ◦ be a binary operation deﬁned over a set G. Then the pair (G, ◦) is called a
group iﬀ ◦
1. is closed w.r.t. G,
2. is associative,
3. has existence of identity element and
4. has existence of inverses.
Furthermore if ◦ is commutative over G then we say that (G, ◦) is an abelian group,
or commutative group.
Remark. An additive (multiplicative) group is one where the binary operation is
addition (multiplication).
Deﬁnition 1.15 (Ring)
Let R = ∅ be a set and ⋆, ◦ be binary operations deﬁned on R. Then the triple
(R, ⋆, ◦) is said to be a ring iﬀ the foll. hold:
1. (R, ⋆) is an abelian group.
2. (R, ◦) is a semigroup.
3. Distributivity:
a) a, b, c ∈ R =⇒ a ◦ (b ⋆ c) = (a ◦ b) ⋆ (a ◦ c).
b) a, b, c ∈ R =⇒ (b ⋆ c) ◦ a = (b ◦ a) ⋆ (c ◦ a).
Remark. In a ring we often use + and · instead of ⋆ and ◦, with (−a), 0 and

1
a

, 1
5
Sayan Das (December 21, 2023) Real Analysis 1
denoting the inverse and identity elements in each case. Moreover, we often write a · b
as ab.
A division ring is a ring which has existence of multiplicative inverse for each nonzero
element within it, i.e. division by nonzero elements is deﬁned.
Remark (Negative times negative is positive). Given a ring (R, +, ·), we have:
1. x, y ∈ R : x + y = 0 =⇒ x + y + (−y) = 0 + (−y) =⇒ x = −y and
x, y, z ∈ R : x + y = x + z =⇒ (−x) + x + y = (−x) + x + z =⇒ y = z.
2. (−x) is the additive inverse of x and x is the additive inverse of (−x); replacing x
with (−x) we get that the additive inverse of (−x) is −(−x), so
−(−x) + (−x) = 0 = x + (−x) =⇒ −(−x) = x.
3. x ∈ R =⇒ 0x = (0 + 0)x = 0x + 0x =⇒ 0 = 0x.
4. x, y ∈ R =⇒ x(−y) + xy = x((−y) + y) = 0 =⇒ x(−y) = −(xy) and
x, y ∈ R =⇒ (−x)y + xy = ((−x) + x)y = 0 =⇒ (−x)y = −(xy) = x(−y).
5. Thus, (−1)1 = −(1 · 1) = −1 = 1(−1) and (−1)(−1) = −((−1)1) = −(−(1 · 1)) =
1 · 1 = 1.

Deﬁnition 1.17 (Field Axioms)
Let F = ∅ be a set with two binary additions deﬁned on it, namely addition (+)
and multiplication (·), s.t. the foll. axioms hold:
1. (F, +) is an abelian additive group.
2. (F \ {0}, ·) is an abelian multiplicative group.
3. Distributivity: · is distributive w.r.t. +.
a · (b + c) = (a · b) + (a · c) ∀a, b, c ∈ F.
We then say that the triple (F, +, ·) is a ﬁeld.
Remark. One may also deﬁne a ﬁeld to be a commutative division ring.
Example 1.18
Q, R, C, Z/pZ for prime p, {a + b
√
2 : a, b ∈ Z} are some examples of ﬁelds.

Deﬁnition 1.19
Let F be a ﬁeld. Then the characteristic of F is the least positive number of
copies of its multiplicative identity 1 that will sum to its additive identity 0, denoted
char(F):
char(F)

Lemma 1.20
A ﬁeld’s characteristic is either 0 or p (where p is prime).
Deﬁnition 1.21 (Partially ordered set)
A partially ordered set (poset) is a set X with a relation ≺ s.t.:
1. If x ∈ X, then x ≺ x. (irreﬂexivity)
2. If x, y ∈ X s.t. x ≺ y and y ≺ x, then x = y. (antisymmetry)
3. If x, y, z ∈ X, x ≺ y and y ≺ z, then x ≺ z. (transitivity)
Remark. Here we’re using a strict ordering ≺ to deﬁne a poset. We could instead use
a weak ordering ⪯, in which case we’d just have to replace irreﬂexivity with reﬂexivity.
Deﬁnition 1.22 (Totally ordered set)
A totally ordered set, linearly ordered set, or simply ordered set, is a poset
X with a relation < in which any two elements are comparable s.t.:
1. If x, y, z ∈ X, x < y and y < z, then x < z. (transitivity)
2. If x, y ∈ X, exactly one of the foll. holds: x < y, x = y, y < x. (trichotomy)
A totally ordered set is also called a chain.
Remark. We call a set a totally ordered set, as opposed to simply an ordered set, when
we want to emphasize the order is total, i.e. every pair of elements are related to each
other, as opposed to a partial order, where every pair of elements need not be related to
each other.
Deﬁnition 1.23 (Maximal and Minimal)
An element x in a poset (X, ≺) is maximal iﬀ x ≺ y =⇒ y /∈ X.
An element x in a poset (X, ≺) is minimal iﬀ y ≺ x =⇒ y /∈ X.
Deﬁnition 1.24 (Bounded sets)
Let (X, ≤) be an poset and let A ⊆ X. An upper bound for A is an element
x ∈ X such that a ∈ A =⇒ a ≤ x. If A has an upper bound, then we say that A
is bounded above.
7
Sayan Das (December 21, 2023) Real Analysis 1
A lower bound for A is an element x ∈ X such that a ∈ A =⇒ x ≤ a. If A has a
lower bound, then we say that A is bounded below.
A is bounded in X iﬀ it is bounded above and below in X.
Deﬁnition 1.25 (Suprema and Inﬁma)
Let (X, ≤) be an poset and let A ⊆ X. An upper bound α is a least upper bound
or supremum of A in X if whenever β < α, β is not an upper bound of A. That
is:
1. (∀a ∈ A) a ≤ α
2. (∀β < α)(∃a ∈ A) β < a
and we write α = sup A ∈ X.
If sup A ∈ A, then we call it max A, the maximum of A.
A lower bound α is a greatest lower bound or inﬁmum of A in X if whenever
α < β, β is not a lower bound of A. That is:
1. (∀a ∈ A) α ≤ a
2. (∀α < β)(∃a ∈ A) a < β
and we write α = inf A ∈ X.
If inf A ∈ A, then we call it min A, the minimum of A.
Deﬁnition 1.26 (Order Complete)
A poset X is order complete iﬀ supremum and inﬁmum of each bounded nonempty
subset A ⊆ X exist and belong to A.
Remark. For a totally ordered set, its supremum and inﬁmum (if they exist) are unique.
Deﬁnition 1.27 (Ordered Field)
An ordered ﬁeld is a ﬁeld F with a total order < s.t.
1. if x, y, z ∈ F and x < y, then x + z < y + z
2. if x, y, z ∈ F, x < y and z > 0, then xz < yz

Lemma 1.30 (Zorn’s Lemma)
If every chain in a poset X is bounded above, then X has a maximal element.

1.2 Construction of R
We will deﬁne R as the completion of Q, thus making it a complete ordered ﬁeld. We can
achieve this using Dedekind cuts or Cauchy sequences: we demonstrate using Dedekind
cuts at the end of this subsection and using Cauchy sequences in the next.
Theorem 1.32
Let F be an ordered ﬁeld and ∅ = A ⊆ F; write
−A = {−x : x ∈ A}
for the set of additive inverses of the elements of A. Let c ∈ F.
1. c is an upper bound of A ⇐⇒ −c is a lower bound of −A.
2. c is a lower bound of A ⇐⇒ −c is an upper bound of −A.
3. If A has a supremum then −A has an inﬁmum and
inf(−A) = −sup A.
4. If A has an inﬁmum then −A has a supremum and
sup(−A) = −inf A.
Deﬁnition 1.33 (Completeness Property)
An ordered ﬁeld F is said to be complete or said to have the supremum property
if every nonempty subset of F that is bounded above has a supremum.
Theorem 1.34 (Dual of Completeness Property)
Let F be a complete ordered ﬁeld and ∅ = A ⊆ F be bounded below in F. Then the

inﬁmum of A exists and
inf A = −sup(−A).
Deﬁnition 1.35 (Dedekind cuts)
A Dedekind cut in Q is a pair of nonempty subsets A, B of Q s.t.:
1. A ∪ B = Q , A ∩ B = ∅.
2. a ∈ A , b ∈ B =⇒ a < b.
3. A has no maximum, i.e. sup A /∈ A.
We call A the left-hand part and B the right-hand part of the cut, and denote the
cut itself by x = A | B.
Deﬁnition 1.36 (A real number is a Dedekind cut)
A real number r ∈ R is a Dedekind cut in Q, i.e. R is the collection of all Dedekind
cuts in Q.
Example 1.37 1. x = {r ∈ Q : r < 42} | {r ∈ Q : r ≥ 42} and

In the cut x the right-hand part has a minimum. We call it a rational cut, the cut
at the rational number 42 and denote the cut itself by 42

Theorem 1.39 (Real numbers)
The triple (R, +, ·) with the total order < is a complete ordered ﬁeld and we call it
the ﬁeld of real numbers.
Proof Outline. Essentially need to “just” verify that the ﬁeld axioms and deﬁnition
of ordered ﬁeld hold for (R, +, ·) equipped with the total order <.
Lemma 1.40 (Archimedean property)
Let F be a complete ordered ﬁeld s.t. the set N ⊆ F. Then N is unbounded above.
Equivalently,
∀x, y ∈ F : x > 0 ∃ n ∈ N s.t. nx > y.
Proof. As ∅ = N ⊆ F, if N is bounded above then there is some α = sup N. Then
α − 1 is not an upper bound of N. So we can ﬁnd n ∈ N such that n > α − 1. But
then n + 1 > α, so that α is not the least upper bound of N. Contradiction.
Now to prove that ∀x > 0 ∃ n ∈ N s.t. nx > y, it suﬃces to show that n > y/x.
Sps for contradiction that there is no such n. Then ∀n ∈ N we must have n ≤
y/x =⇒ y/x is an upper bound of N. Contradiction.
Remark. There are non-complete ordered ﬁelds that are non-Archimedean i.e. in which
the integers are bounded above. Consider the ﬁeld of rational functions, i.e. functions
in the form
p(x)
q(x)
with p(x), q(x) being polynomials, under the usual addition and multiplication. We
order two functions
p(x)
q(x)
,
r(x)
s(x)
as follows: these two functions intersect only ﬁnitely many times because
p(x)s(x) = r(x)q(x)
has only ﬁnitely many roots. After the last intersection, the function whose value is
greater counts as the greater function. It can be checked that these form an ordered
ﬁeld.
In this ﬁeld, the integers are the constant functions 1, 2, 3, . . . , but it is bounded above
since the function x is greater than all of them.

Sayan Das (December 21, 2023) Real Analysis 1
§
1.3 Cardinality of inﬁnite sets
The intuition regarding the cardinalities of ﬁnite sets does not always hold up for inﬁnite
sets, so we need a general deﬁnition to cover both cases.
Deﬁnition 1.41 (Set Cardinality)
We say that two sets have the same cardinality iﬀ there exists some bijection between
them.
Deﬁnition 1.42 (Countable and Uncountable Sets)
An inﬁnite set X is countable iﬀ there is a bijection f : N → X. Otherwise, X is
uncountable.
§
1.4 Topology of the real line
Deﬁnition 1.43
A metric space is a pair (X, d) where X is a nonempty set of points and
d : X ×X → R (called the distance function or metric) s.t.:
1. d(x, y) ≥ 0 with d(x, y) = 0 ⇐⇒ x = y. (positive deﬁniteness)
2. d(x, y) = d(y, x). (symmetry)
3. d(x, y) ≤ d(x, z) + d(z, y). (triangle inequality)
Example 1.44
The most natural example of a metric space is R
n
, the Euclidean n-space. Here
we consider the metric to be induced from the standard Euclidean norm ∥x∥ :=
q
P
n
j=1
x
2
j
. However, other norms also exist.
Q is also a metric space, albeit not a complete one. R is a complete metric space,
in fact using Cauchy sequences we can deﬁne it to be the completion of Q w.r.t. the
standard Euclidean metric.
Deﬁnition 1.45 (Sequence)
A sequence in the metric space X is a mapping f : A → X where A ⊆ N.
If |A| = ℵ

Deﬁnition 1.46 (Neighbourhoods)
12
Sayan Das (December 21, 2023) Real Analysis 1
Let X be a metric space and ε > 0. An (ε-)neighbourhood of p ∈ X is deﬁned as
the set:
N(p; ε) := {q ∈ X : d(p, q) ≤ ε}.
Further, a deleted (ε-)neighbourhood of p is deﬁned as the ε-neighbourhood of
p excluding p itself:
N
′
(p; ε) := N(p; ε) \ {p}.
Example 1.47
The easiest example of a neighbourhood is probably the open interval in R,
(a, b) = {x ∈ R : a < x < b}.
Deﬁnition 1.48 (Interior points)
Let X be a metric space. A point p ∈ X is an interior point of E ⊆ X iﬀ there is
at least one neighbourhood of p that is contained in E. The interior int E of E is
the set of all interior points of E. Thus:
p ∈ int E ⇐⇒ (∃ε > 0 : N(p; ε) ⊆ E) .
Example 1.49
Assume here that X = R, then
int [a, b] = int (a, b] = int [a, b) = int (a, b) = (a, b).
Countable and discrete subsets of R have no interior,
Let S ⊂ Z, then
int S = int Z = int N = int Q = ∅.
However,
int ((a, b) ∪ S) = (a, b).
The irrationals are uncountable but any neighbourhood (open interval) in R contains
both rationals and irrationals. Thus,
int Q = ∅.
Deﬁnition 1.50 (Open sets)
Let X be a metric space and E ⊆ X. Then E is open iﬀ E = int E i.e. every point
in E is an interior point of E.
Equivalently, E is open iﬀ
(∀x ∈ E) ∃ε > 0 : N(p; ε) ⊆ E.

Every neighbourhood is an open set.
Corollary 1.52
Every open interval (a, b) is an open set.

some x ∈ G such that ∀ε > 0 : N(p; ε) ⊂ E.
Thus ∅ is open (vacuously true), and R = (−∞, ∞) is open.

Deﬁnition 1.56 (Limit points)
Let X be a metric space. A point p ∈ X is a limit point or cluster point or
accumulation point of E ⊆ X iﬀ every deleted neighbourhood of p contains a

Let X be a metric space. A point p ∈ X is an isolated point of E ⊆ X iﬀ p ∈ E

Deﬁnition 1.59 (Perfect sets)
Let X be a metric space and E ⊆ X. Then E is perfect iﬀ E is closed and every
point in E is a limit point of E.
Deﬁnition 1.60 (Bounded sets)
Let X be a metric space and E ⊆ X. E is bounded iﬀ there is M ∈ R and q ∈ X
s.t. d(p, q) < M ∀p ∈ E.

Deﬁnition 1.61 (Dense sets)
Let X be a metric space and E ⊆ X. E is dense in X iﬀ every point of X is in the
closure of E i.e. X = cl E.
Example 1.62
Q is dense in R.
Theorem 1.63
E is open iﬀ its complement X \ E is closed.
Corollary 1.64
E is closed iﬀ its complement X \ E is open.

2 Sequences
Having deﬁned real numbers, the ﬁrst thing we will study is sequences. We will want to
study what it means for a sequence to converge. Intuitively, we would like to say that

deﬁnition of convergence is rather hard to get right, and historically there have been
failed attempts that produced spurious results.

2.1 Deﬁnitions

A sequence is, formally, a function a : N → R (or C). Usually (i.e. always), we write

In symbols, this says
(∀ε > 0)(∃N)(∀n ≥ N) |a

We say ℓ is the limit of (a

One can think of (∃N )(∀n ≥ N) as saying “eventually always”, or as “from some point

in the sequence is within ε of ℓ.
Lemma 2.3
1/n → 0.
18
Sayan Das (December 21, 2023) Real Analysis 1
Proof. Let ε > 0. We want to ﬁnd an N such that |1/N −0| = 1/N < ε. So pick N
such that N > 1/ε. There exists such an N by the Archimedean property v1. Then
for all n ≥ N, we have 0 < 1/n ≤ 1/N < ε. So |1/n − 0| < ε.
Note that the red parts correspond to the deﬁnition of convergence of a sequence. This
is generally how we prove convergence from ﬁrst principles.
Deﬁnition 2.4 (Bounded sequence)
A sequence (a

(∃C)(∀n) |a

A sequence is eventually bounded if
(∃C)(∃N)(∀n ≥ N) |a

The deﬁnition of an eventually bounded sequence seems a bit daft. Clearly every even-
tually bounded sequence is bounded! Indeed it is:

sequence is eventually bounded, and this lemma saves us from writing that long line
every time.

2.3 Monotone-sequences property
Recall that we characterized the least upper bound property. It turns out that there is
an alternative characterization of real number using sequences, known as the monotone-
sequences property. In this section, we will show that the two characterizations are
equivalent, and use the monotone-sequences property to deduce some useful results.

It is strictly increasing if a

A sequence is (strictly) monotone if it is (strictly) increasing or (strictly) decreasing.
Deﬁnition 2.18 (Monotone-sequences property)
An ordered ﬁeld has the monotone sequences property if every increasing sequence
that is bounded above converges.
We want to show that the monotone sequences property is equivalent to the least upper
bound property.
Lemma 2.19

Proof. Let (a

Lemma 2.21
Monotone-sequences property ⇒ Archimedean property.
Proof. We prove version 2, i.e. that 1/n → 0.
Since 1/n > 0 and is decreasing, by MSP, it converges. Let δ be the limit. By the
previous lemma, we must have δ ≥ 0.
If δ > 0, then we can ﬁnd N such that 1/N < 2δ. But then for all n ≥ 4N, we have
1/n ≤ 1/(4N) < δ/2. Contradiction. Therefore δ = 0.

2.4 Cauchy sequences
The third characterization of real numbers is in terms of Cauchy sequences. Cauchy con-
vergence is an alternative way of deﬁning convergent sequences without needing to men-
tion the actual limit of the sequence. This allows us to say {3, 3.1, 3.14, 3.141, 3.1415, . . . }
is Cauchy convergent in Q even though the limit π is not in Q.
Deﬁnition 2.29 (Cauchy sequence)
A sequence (a
n
) is Cauchy if for all ε, there is some N ∈ N such that whenever
p, q ≥ N, we have |a
p
− a
q
| < ε. In symbols, we have
(∀ε > 0)(∃N)(∀p, q ≥ N) |a
p
− a
q
| < ε.
Roughly, a sequence is Cauchy if all terms are eventually close to each other (as opposed
to close to a limit).
Lemma 2.30
Every convergent sequence is Cauchy.
Proof. Let a
n
→ a. Let ε > 0. Then ∃N such that ∀n ≥ N, |a
n
− a| < ε/2. Then
∀p, q ≥ N, |a
p
− a
q
| ≤ |a
p
− a| + |a − a

| < ε/2 + ε/2 = ε.
Lemma 2.31
Let (a

Proof. Let ε > 0. Pick N such that ∀p, q ≥ N, |a

An important result we have is that in R, Cauchy convergence and regular convergence
are equivalent.
Theorem 2.32 (The general principle of convergence)
Let F be an ordered ﬁeld with the monotone-sequence property. Then every Cauchy
sequence of F converges.
Proof. Let (a

) be a Cauchy sequence. Then it is eventually bounded, since ∃N ,
∀n ≥ N, |a

− a

Bolzano-Weierstrass, it has a convergent subsequence. Then (a

same limit.
Deﬁnition 2.33 (Complete ordered ﬁeld)
An ordered ﬁeld in which every Cauchy sequence converges is called complete.
Hence we say that R is a complete ordered ﬁeld.
However, not every complete ordered ﬁeld is (isomorphic to) R. For example, we can
take the rational functions as before, then take the Cauchy completion of it (i.e. add all
the limits we need). Then it is already too large to be the reals (it still doesn’t have the
Archimedean property) but is a complete ordered ﬁeld.
To show that completeness implies the monotone-sequences property, we need an addi-
tional condition: the Archimedean property.
Lemma 2.34
Let F be an ordered ﬁeld with the Archimedean property such that every Cauchy
sequence converges. The F satisﬁes the monotone-sequences property.
Proof. Instead of showing that every bounded monotone sequence converges, and
is hence Cauchy, We will show the equivalent statement that every increasing non-
Cauchy sequence is not bounded above.
Let (a

(∃ε > 0)(∀N)(∃p, q > N) |a

Sayan Das (December 21, 2023) Real Analysis 1
Therefore

Note that the deﬁnition of a convergent sequence is
(∃l)(∀ε > 0)(∃N)(∀n ≥ N) |a

while that of Cauchy convergence is
(∀ε > 0)(∃N)(∀p, q ≥ N) |a

In the ﬁrst deﬁnition, l quantiﬁes over all real numbers, which is uncountable. How-
ever, in the second deﬁnition, we only have to quantify over natural numbers, which is
countable (by the Archimedean property, we only have to consider the cases ε = 1/n).
Since they are equivalent in R, the second deﬁnition is sometimes preferred when we
care about logical simplicity.

3.4 Complex versions
Most deﬁnitions in the course so far carry over unchanged to the complex numbers. e.g.
z
n
→ z iﬀ (∀ε > 0)(∃N)(∀n ≥ N) |z
n
− z| < ε.
Two exceptions are least upper bound and monotone sequences, because the complex
numbers do not have an ordering! (It cannot be made into an ordered ﬁeld because
the square of every number in an ordered ﬁeld has to be positive) Fortunately, Cauchy
sequences still work.
We can prove the complex versions of most theorems so far by looking at the real and
imaginary parts.
Example 3.23
Let (z
n
) be a Cauchy sequence in C. Let z
n
= x
n
+ iy

Cauchy. So they converge, from which it follows that z

= x

converges.
Also, the Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem still holds: If (z
n
) is bounded, let z
n
= x
n
+ y

,
then (x

) and (y

n
k
) that converges. Then
ﬁnd a subsequence of (y
n
k
) that converges.
Then nested-intervals property has a “nested-box” property as a complex analogue.
Finally, the proof that absolutely convergent sequences converge still works. It follows
that the ratio test still works.
